title: 109_hr2297
content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE; FINDINGS; PURPOSES." is a condensed summary of the section that includes the short title, findings, and purposes of the document. The "Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area Act" recognizes the Arabia Mountain area's natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources. It emphasizes partnerships between public and private entities for resource management. The Davidson-Arabia Mountain Nature Preserve and Panola Mountain are highlighted for their conservation efforts. Panola Mountain, located in Panola Mountain State Conservation Park, is a rare granite outcrop. Miners Creek Preserve shows evidence of early human activity. Lithonia, Georgia, Arabia Mountain, and Stone Mountain display the history of granite mining. Klondike is eligible for National Historic District designation. Lithonia has 2 structures on the National Register of Historic Places. The Act aims to preserve natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources in the area. The Act aims to protect and interpret historical, scenic, and recreational resources in the area including Arabia Mountain, Panola Mountain, Miners Creek, and other significant sites. It assists Georgia and the counties of DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry in developing a cultural, historical, and land resource management program for the heritage area. The Act defines key terms such as "heritage area," "management entity," "management plan," "Secretary," and "State." It establishes the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area and specifies the responsible management entity as the DeKalb County Parks and Recreation Department or its successor. The Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area is established in the State, encompassing land in DeKalb, Rockdale, and Henry counties. The map of the area is available for public inspection. The Arabia Mountain Heritage Area Alliance is designated as the management entity for the heritage area. The management entity has authorities and duties outlined in the Act. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area has authorities to make grants, hire staff, and enter contracts. They are required to develop and submit a management plan considering diverse interests. Priorities include assisting in preserving resources within the heritage area. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area is responsible for assisting government and nonprofit organizations in resource preservation, encouraging local governments to adopt land use policies consistent with the management plan, conducting quarterly public meetings, submitting an annual report on accomplishments and finances, and allowing audits of all expenditure records. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area must provide all expenditure records for audit, including those of receiving organizations. Federal funds cannot be used to acquire real property, but other federal funds can be used for authorized purposes. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area must provide expenditure records for audit, including those of receiving organizations. Federal funds cannot be used to acquire real property, but can be used for authorized purposes. The management entity for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area must develop a management plan based on the preferred concept from a feasibility study. The plan should consider state and local plans, involve residents, public agencies, and private organizations, and include an inventory of resources in the heritage area that should be preserved or managed. The management plan for the Arabia Mountain National Heritage Area should include provisions for protection, interpretation, and enjoyment of resources, an interpretation plan, implementation program involving various entities, and evaluation of the management entity for approval by the Secretary. The management entity must submit the management plan to the Secretary for approval within 3 years of the Act's enactment. Failure to submit the plan will result in a halt of additional funding. The Secretary will approve or disapprove the plan within 90 days of receiving it, with the option for revision if disapproved. After the Secretary disapproves a management plan, they must advise the entity of reasons, make recommendations for revisions, and allow for resubmission. The Secretary must approve or disapprove revisions within 90 days. The management entity must periodically review and submit plan recommendations for approval. The management entity must periodically review and submit plan recommendations for approval by the Secretary. No funds can be used to implement any proposed revisions until approved by the Secretary. The Secretary may provide technical and financial assistance to the heritage area for developing and implementing the management plan, prioritizing actions that conserve natural, cultural, historical, and recreational resources. This assistance should also focus on providing educational and recreational opportunities consistent with the area's values. The Act ensures that no new regulations are imposed on the heritage area that are more stringent than existing regulations, and it does not grant zoning powers to the management entity. SEC. 8 outlines the requirements for including private property in the Heritage Area, stating that written notification and consent from property owners are necessary. Property owners can request the removal of their property from the boundary. SEC. 9 focuses on protecting private property within the Heritage Area. The Act ensures that private property owners are not required to allow public access or modify existing laws regarding access. It also states that designation as a Heritage Area does not create liability for property owners. Additionally, it clarifies that participation in the Heritage Area is not mandatory for property owners within its boundaries. The boundaries represent the area eligible for federal funds. The establishment of the Heritage Area and its boundaries allows for the expenditure of federal funds within the designated area, without granting regulatory authority over land use to the Secretary, National Park Service, or management entity. Authorization of $10,000,000 for the Act, with a limit of $1,000,000 per fiscal year. Federal share not to exceed 50%. Secretary's authority to provide assistance ends on September 30, 2016.
